i know
so did i once
our consciences were clear now
now all is safe and sound
i will and can do so¶no one could lie down
confidence increased
an occasion was soon found
no one else was injured¶we looked around
i was all alone
well i know
one window and four doors
i dislike crowds and noise¶no one will see us
red cloud
i was a winner
of course
a silence fell
kick once
we faced a cold wind¶duck under sofa
and i wondered
essence underlies influence
decrease in loudness of sound
reason is confounded¶

sub.name: Text exercise 2
sub.type_text:
know life
all is confusion and disorder
sure we can
no one can see us and we can see no one
dinner was now announced¶i was accursed
and now we are free
all nodded concurrence
i was sick of work
our linen
i asked once
son is safe
no a word¶i saw a rider
red owen
all is done
i like saloons
we worked in silence
slick as silk
we were now in darkness
no one saw our faces¶no indeed
all noise ceased
we saw a wilderness
snow nodded
now i know
i was reckless and i knew fear
sacks laid crosswise
one was a coon¶

sub.name: Text exercise 1
sub.type_text: Like a wild Indian. Dear Friend. O Lord. London in UK. Oakland, CALIFORNIA. In Dawson. Carl and Joe. Carroll and Ken.¶Eddison and Franklin. Frona and Joan. Frank and Fred. Lon and Edwin. Duncan, Raoul and Daw. Nick and Erin. Lad and Kaluna.¶Close doors and windows. Alice was indeed in Wonderland. Of course, we know no one in Warsaw. Jack was a nice feller.¶No offence, said Dan. India was far, London was near. Row, said Duncan, and Aaron rowed and rowed. Successes and failures.¶Diana looked confused. Anne looked around. We can and we will, assured Jessie. We know now our friends and our foes.¶

sub.name: Text exercise 2
sub.type_text: And no one else will know. Our decision was a sudden one. Florence was flaccid. Dinner was a success. Jake could confide.¶Frank was conscious of a sense of relief. Collins cared less now. I need a friend now. Of course we could, Dennin declared.¶Edna and I once did so. Scene followed scene. London was now awake. We were indeed in Africa. I will send Annie.¶I looked around and could see no one. Nolan was in France now. San Francisco is wonderful, of course. Darkness fell on a scene of wild confusion.¶

sub.name: Text exercise 1
sub.type_text: I never said so. Summer came on. Answer me. No jams nor jellies. I came, I saw, I overcame.¶Never found one in uniform. Never mind and once more no. Summer, salmon and river. Never were sounds more welcome.¶We love Mercedes limousine. Condensed milk makes marvelous cocoa. I never was married, Miss. A cousin of mine married Jones.¶And our fears were confirmed. Asked in alarm. I am a frank man, and frankness never offends me. A snake never looked more venomous.¶

sub.name: Text exercise 2
sub.type_text: Never a sound came from mind more like a scream. No one ever recovered. None so slow like a worker of miracles. No man answered, no man moved.¶A new sound commenced. Four miles, come now and discover. Small wonder and one is alive. I made new rules. Well, never mind. Moreover, I am a civilised man.¶Never were dreams more vivid. Men are men, and women are women. Indian summer, mild and warm. I confess I was never more moved. Make some allowance for me.¶

sub.name: Text exercise 1
sub.type_text: Certain shorthand date formats use / as a delimiter, for example "6/21/1788" June 21, 1788.¶For example, 12~15 means "12 to 15", ~3 means "up to three" and 100~ means "100 and greater."¶

sub.name: Text exercise 2
sub.type_text: Certain prefixes (co-, pre-, mid-, de-, non-, anti-, etc.) may or may not be hyphenated. Hyphens are occasionally used to denote syllabification, as in syl-la-bi-fi-ca-tion.¶The at sign (@), also called the at symbol or asperand, is formally an abbreviation of the accounting and commercial invoice term "at the rate of" (e.g., 9 widgets @ $3 = $27).¶

name: Typing test
text_type: A bone that he had swallowed stuck in the jaws of a Wolf. Thereupon, overcome by extreme pain, he began to tempt all and sundry by great rewards to extract the cause of misery. At length, on his taking an oath, a Crane was prevailed on, and, trusting the length of her neck to his throat, she wrought, with danger to herself, a cure for the Wolf. When she demanded the promised reward for this service, "You are an ungrateful one," replied the Wolf, "to have taken your head in safety out of my mouth, and then to ask for a reward."¶
